misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The submitted program computes the distance between two points instead of reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on the specified ranges. There is no handling of grade input or conditional logic for mapping to letter grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that implementing a distance-between-points calculator (reading x1, y1, x2, y2 and computing a Euclidean distance) is the required task, or they may have accidentally submitted code for a different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read a single integer or double representing a grade from 0 to 100, then use conditional statements to determine whether it falls in the ranges for A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), or F (below 60), and finally print the correct letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for coordinate pairs ("Enter x1 and y1:", "Enter x2 and y2:") instead of a single grade.
Inputs are stored in variables x1, y1, x2, y2 rather than a grade variable.
The calculation performed is a square root of dx*dx + dy*dy, representing distance, not any grade comparison.
Output text is "The distance of the two points is ..." instead of a letter grade such as "Letter grade: B".
There are no if/else or conditional checks on a grade value.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or accidental reuse/submission of code for a separate problem involving distance between points instead of the grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-between-points logic and re-implement the program to (1) read a single numeric grade from the user, and (2) use if/else-if/else statements to test the grade against the given ranges and print the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Input and output basics in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompts, variables, calculations, and output) is consistent with a distance calculator and entirely unrelated to the requested grade calculator logic.

evidence.note: Entire program is a distance-between-points calculator; it never reads a grade, uses conditional ranges, or prints a letter grade as required by the grade calculator problem.

misconceptions.name: Implemented solution for a different problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points (a standard geometry problem) instead of the required Grade Calculator program. This fundamental error means none of the grading logic tasks were attempted.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted a solution for a different assignment, believing it satisfied the 'Grade Calculator' requirement, or they fundamentally misunderstood the goal.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to map that number to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: The program prompts for and reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2).
The program calculates distance using the Pythagorean/distance formula.
Contains no conditional logic related to grade ranges.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment prompt or submitting code belonging to a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and ensure the submitted code reads a single grade and maps it to a letter grade using conditional logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is a textbook example of calculating the distance between two points, which is completely unrelated to the required task of calculating a letter grade.

evidence.note: The entire code implements the distance formula and prompts for coordinates, not a grade calculator.

misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch - wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. This suggests either a copy-paste error, submission of wrong file, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem rather than a grade conversion problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of converting grades to letters
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely submission of incorrect file or copy-paste from a different assignment/tutorial
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with this problem: read a single integer grade, then use if-else statements to check ranges (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.) and print the corresponding letter.
related_concepts: Reading single value input with Scanner
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (geometry/distance) than what was assigned (grade conversion). The mismatch is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Program requests coordinates instead of a grade; completely wrong input for the assignment
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of performing grade conversion logic

misconceptions.task: Overall problem solving / implementing the required program
misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem instead of the grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade using conditional logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a program computing the distance between two points is an acceptable solution for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program must read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional statements to map it to the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) and print that letter.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade
No use of a variable representing grade
No conditional (if/else) logic to classify grades into A/B/C/D/F ranges
Output describes distance between points rather than a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignments or reuse of code for a different textbook/example problem (distance formula) instead of implementing the specified grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard or set aside this distance-formula code and start a new program that: (1) reads a single numeric grade; (2) uses if/else-if/else to check the numeric range (90-100, 80-89, etc.); and (3) prints the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Program design from a textual description
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and all variables, prompts, and output correspond to the distance-between-points problem and contain no elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: The program reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade from 0-100.
The logic computes and prints the distance between two points rather than determining and printing a letter grade based on the input.

misconceptions.name: Solved wrong problem (Distance Calculation instead of Grade Calculation)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points, which is entirely unrelated to the requested task of calculating a letter grade based on a numeric score. The required logic (conditionals/ranges) is completely missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or submitted code for a completely different assignment requiring distance calculation, or fundamentally misunderstood the purpose of this specific question, providing a solution that calculates distance instead of solving the grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if-else if-else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Inputs requested are (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) instead of a single grade
Conditional logic (if/else structure) is completely absent
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misidentification of the required task or submission of incorrect code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully and construct the program using 'if' and 'else if' statements to check the input grade against the specified ranges (90+, 80-89, etc.).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code implements the distance formula and asks for four coordinate inputs, directly contradicting every requirement of the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The class name and input prompts indicate a distance calculation program, not a grade calculator.
The core logic calculates the Euclidean distance, demonstrating a complete deviation from the required task of grade evaluation.
